column4: Hey all, I don't remember the person that helped me get my partition mounted in Ubuntu, but it's not allowing anything to be marked as executable now..
nls=iso8859-1,umask=7133,dmask=7022,gid=jimmi,owner,uid=jimmi is my current Options portion of the fstab line. What do I do?
What filesystem is this -- ext? ntfs? vfat?
NTFS
NTFS does not support Unix permissions, and it is not possible to mark something as "executable" if it's stored on a NTFS partition.
Sorry, but it is. I do it all the time. .sh is executable. Says me. I have the masks set wrong I'll bet
First, Unix doesn't use extensions - it uses the "executable" bit that's stored in the file system.
Second, that "executable" bit CANNOT be stored in NTFS systems.
There is simply NO PLACE to store it.
I know that. So I either have to deal with everything trying to execute or nothing? How lame.
NTFS simply is not for Unix. It's for Windows. Those are two very different operating systems.
I realize. I also realize I need >4 gig files, I need to be able to use Windows with the partition, and I also realize I need to run shell scripts without CDing to it from a terminal.
Must the scripts be on that filesystem?
Can't you move them to, for example, ~/bin/  ?
They have to be, yes. Why? I'm programming. The script builds. The scripts change for different projects. I also need to access it from Windows without using a file manager.
Are there many scripts? You could make aliases in bash for them.
It's easier to just change it so everything says it's executable. That's what I'm doing.
So umask=7022?
Metacity is very simple, it doesn't have much features.
Btw, you might want to look at tiling WMs (dwm, awesome, wmii)
I tried awesome. A bit more awesome than I can stand. dwm and wmii I've never heard of.
Yeah, neither Xfce nor GNOME are WMs. (Btw, you can use Xfwm4 on GNOME and vice-versa)
